entry.title: Features and Future Scope in AOSP - Part 2

link.title: Features and Future Scope in AOSP - Part 2

entry.summary: Something that started as a hobby of mine, to something that I do professionally in my daily life. Core Features Modular Architecture Dynamic partitions for seamless A/B updates (and easy rollback) across devices. Many System Components packaged as APEX modules. Mainline Modules allow Google to update system components via Play Store. GKI (Generic Kernel Image) ...

entry.title: Getting Started with AOSP - Part 1
entry.summary: Today marks six years since I compiled my very first Android source build — it was Android 7.0 Nougat. Ever since then, I’ve been deeply involved in Android platform development, and there’s one question that keeps coming back to me, asked by thousands of people: “What does it actually take to get started with AOSP?” If you’re new to the Android Open Source Project, the sheer scale of it can ...

entry.title: Using AOSP Kernel Build
entry.summary: In my previous blog, we talked about how to cross-compile Android Kernel, but there is another official way that ODMs use to compile their kernel sources, via AOSP Kernel Build. This blog covers 2 aspects: Compile using Legacy AOSP Kernel Build Add support for bazel Kernel Build Bazel is an open-source build and test tool from Google. It supports a wide range of programming languages ...

entry.title: Cross-Compiling Android Linux Kernel
entry.summary: When you use your Android device, you’re interacting with a complex system that relies heavily on the Linux kernel at its core. But what exactly is the Android Linux kernel, and how does it work? What is Linux Kernel? The Linux kernel is the core component of the Linux operating system, responsible for managing hardware resources (such as the CPU, memory, and devices), providing essential se...

link.title: LFX Mentorship for Linux Kernel Bug Fixing

entry.summary: Learn more about the Linux Foundation Mentorship programme, and hear from someone who went through the process. What is LFX mentorship? “The Linux Foundation Mentorship Program is designed to help developers — many of whom are first-time open source contributors — with necessary skills and resources to learn, experiment, and contribute effectively to open source communities.
